bestBHT.bht: A voice exclaims in the wilderness, calling for the preparation of the way for the Lord. John the Baptist, though only a voice, had a significant and sacred role as the forerunner of the Messiah. His proclamation reverberates across time, resonating like the couriers who prepared the paths for the king in ancient Persia. Through his message, John paved the way for the arrival of Christ, reminding us of the importance of straightening our paths and readying our hearts for the Lord's coming.

Henry Alford: Had the citation from Isaiah stood first, it would have been of no note, as Meyer observes. Consult notes on Matt. xi. 10; iii. 3.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.

If it be the true one, it is to be explained thus—that of the two quotations, the one from Malachi is but a later development of the great primary one in Isaiah, from which the whole prophetical matter here quoted takes its name.

The chief objection to it is, that if this was the true reading, it is difficult to see how the other one could have got in at all; whereas, if it be not the true reading, it is very easy to see how it found its way into the text, as it removes the startling difficulty of a prophecy beginning with the words of Malachi being ascribed to Isaiah.
Marvin Vincent: No article as A. V. and Rev., “the voice.” It has a sort of exclamatory force. Listening, the prophet exclaims, Lo! a voice.
Archibald T. Robertson: He was only a voice, but we can still hear the echo of that voice through the corridor of the centuries.
Automobile highways today well illustrate the wonderful Persian roads for the couriers of the king and then for the king himself.
John had a high and holy mission as the forerunner of the Messiah.
John Gill: The voice of one crying in the wilderness,.... This is the other testimony in proof of the same, and may be read in Isaiah 40:3.

bhtAttempts.bht: A voice cries out in the wilderness, proclaiming the coming of the Lord and urging the people to prepare and make the paths straight. It is noteworthy that this quote from Isaiah takes precedence over the one from Malachi, as it is the primary and foundational prophecy. Although John the Baptist was merely a voice, we can still hear the echo of his message resonate through the centuries. Just as the Persian roads were prepared for the king and his messengers, John had a crucial role as the forerunner of the Messiah. Through his proclamation in the wilderness, he paved the way for the arrival of Christ.

A voice cries out in the wilderness, proclaiming the coming of the Lord and urging the people to prepare and make the paths straight. John the Baptist, though merely a voice, played a critical role as the forerunner of the Messiah. Just as the Persian roads were prepared for the king and his messengers, John's mission was to pave the way for the arrival of Christ. His message echoes throughout the centuries, reminding us of the importance of preparing our hearts for the coming of the Lord.

A voice cries in the wilderness, urging people to prepare the way for the Lord. John the Baptist, though just a voice, fulfilled a high and holy mission as the forerunner of the Messiah. His message echoes through time, resounding like the couriers paving the way for the king on the Persian roads. Like those highways, John's proclamation prepared the people for the coming of Christ, illustrating the importance of straightening our paths and making our hearts ready for the Lord.

A voice exclaims in the wilderness, calling for the preparation of the way for the Lord. John the Baptist, though only a voice, had a significant and sacred role as the forerunner of the Messiah. His proclamation reverberates across time, resonating like the couriers who prepared the paths for the king in ancient Persia. Through his message, John paved the way for the arrival of Christ, reminding us of the importance of straightening our paths and readying our hearts for the Lord's coming.

In the wilderness, a voice cries out to prepare the way for the Lord. John the Baptist, though merely a voice, played a vital role as the forerunner of the Messiah. His message echoes through time, symbolizing the well-prepared Persian roads for the king's couriers. Through his proclamation, John paved the way for Christ's arrival, reminding us to straighten our paths and ready our hearts for the coming of the Lord.
